results.description:
Program: 

18:00 Doors open - Dinner-Buffet 

19:00 We start 

21:00 We end the session

Speaker: Rik van Bruggen 

Abstract: During this meetup we will have two separate but related presentations and discussions. 

1. We will have an introduction to the wonderful world of Graph Databases, and how they can be compared to traditional relational and other modern NOSQL technologies. 

2. We will illustrate and explore graph databases using one of the most famous and interesting datasets in modern day history: the Panama Papers. The journalists of the ICIJ in fact used Neo4j for their research and uncovering many of the interesting aspects of the research, and we will demonstrate and explore the dataset together to make everyone understand why that was the case. At the end of the meetup, you should have a good understanding of this exciting new database technology, and some real-world examples from the Panama Papers that will spark your interest even more!

Drinks and location provided by:
results.name: Neo4j and the Panama papers

results.description:
Elevator Saga (play.elevatorsaga.com) is a fun and challenging game that helps you learn JavaScript. Join us as we write some code together and see how many levels we can solve! We'll work in pairs or small groups. 

Do not forget to bring your laptop and charger!

Program: 

18:00 Doors open - Dinner

19:00 We start!

21:00 We end the session

Food, drinks and location provided by:
results.name: Learn JavaScript by playing Elevator Saga together!

results.description:
Speaker: Frank Scholten, Senior Software Engineer - Container Solutions

Program:

18:00 Doors open - food

19:00 Talk and some hands-on, bring your laptop!

21:00 Official end

Prerequisites: 

The containers in this Makefile are necessary:

https://github.com/ContainerSolutions/minimesos/blob/master/Makefile 

Furthermore: Make sure docker is installed on Linux or Docker for Mac

Abstract: Apache Mesos allows you to use a cluster of machines as if it were a single pool of CPU, memory and disk resources. Applications running on Mesos, also called frameworks, can use Mesos' APIs to schedule processes or containers across the cluster and implement features such as failover and autoscaling. During the development of the Elastic stack on Mesos (Elasticsearch, Logstash and Kibana) we found that the Mesos and Docker community is missing to locally develop and tests these Mesos frameworks. We decided to create our own tool for experimenting and testing Mesos called minimesos. It is available at http://www.minimesos.org

Minimesos is an experimentation and testing tool that has a cli and a Java API which can be used from a JUnit test. You can start a Dockerized Mesos cluster, install Marathon apps and view the cluster state. Minimesos works on Linux with Docker and Docker on Mac has also been supported recently. For easy experimentation we support Mesos DNS so applications are resolvable on the .mm domain.In this talk I will introduce minimesos, it's features, design and implementation and what is on the horizon. After the talk there is time for some hands-on experimentation to deploy your application of choice on minimesos, ask questions and give suggestions and feedback on minimesos. 

For  hands-on experimentation please install the prerequisites.

Foods and drinks powered by:
results.name: Intro into Minimesos with hands-on

results.description:
Program:

18:00 Doors open - diner & drinks

19:00 Session begins!

21:00 Official end

Innovate with Cognitive IoT

The impact of the Internet of Things on the way we run our businesses is unprecedented. Business models will change drastically, the IoT is unlocking competitive possibilities we could not imagine before. From refrigerators to cars, from buildings to machines, from water management systems to medical equipment, from elevators to our shoes, everything has sensors, everything is connected and is generating huge amounts of data. And we can use that data. Data is the new gold.Sensor data can help us to innovate, can help us to re-invent our businesses. But how? And why? Do we have a choice? And if we want to use the sensor data to innovate what do we need? Is it hard to connect devices? 

IBM is helping companies on this journey. The amounts of data already is beyond imagination, and lots of these data is unstructured and not easy to access. Traditional analysis methodologies and techniques are often no longer usable. Watson, the IBM cognitive computing system, will help us to unlock this data and turn it into information we can use in our advantage. 

In this meeting Sonja Mols and Arjen van de Wetering from IBM will tell you more about Cognitive IoT, and demonstrate how easy it already is to use this technology.
results.name: Innovate with Cognitive IoT

results.description:
Program:

18:00 Doors open - dinner & drinks

19:00 Session begins!

21:00 Official end, have a chat/drink

Speaker: Professor Jurgen Vinju (https://www.linkedin.com/in/jurgenvinju/)

We know that most of a software engineers' time is spent answering questions about existing software, because even simple questions can be hard or costly to answer. Most of the time, the sheer volume of the source code makes it impossible to fully read and understand the code manually in order to answer such a question. An example question, let's say during a debugging session is: "could it be a bug in one of our hashcode() or equals() implementations?". A simple yes answer would solve the bug, a no answer would allow us to move on and form another hypothesis, but getting this simple answer requires a big code reading investment or an investment in writing a lot of new test code.

In this talk we explore the ins and outs of treating the software itself as data, with an associated query and analysis technique to automated (partly) the information retrieval part of answering software questions. We introduce the ideas and concepts and a concrete tool to quickly build your own code analysis tools. The presentation ends with a hands-on example for finding violations of the hashcode()/equals() contract in Java code.

Food & Drinks powerd by:
results.name: What if… [y]our code were data?

results.description:
Program:

18:00 Doors open - dinner & drinks

18:30 Workshop begins

21:00 Official end, have a chat/drink

Speaker: Robert van Rijn

Requirements: Get this repo: workshop and follow the steps in the README.md then you will have the dependencies.

In this workshop we will work with Apache Kafka Connect.

Kafka Connect is a framework included in Apache Kafka that integrates Kafka with other systems. Its purpose is to make it easy to add new systems to your scalable and secure stream data pipelines.

To copy data between Kafka and another system, users instantiate Kafka Connectors for the systems they want to pull data from or push data to. Source Connectors import data from another system (e.g. a relational database into Kafka) and Sink Connectors export data (e.g. the contents of a Kafka topic to an HDFS file).

You will learn how to use different sources and sinks and have a pleasent evening with your peers! See ya all there!

Food & Drinks powerd by:
results.name: Workshop: Apache Kafka Connect

results.description:
Program:

18:00 Doors open - dinner & drinks

19:00 Session begins

21:00 Official end, have a chat/drink

Speaker: Fabio Tiriticco

Abstract: The word 'Reactive' seems to be all over the place these days - and together with it, a great deal of confusion. We'll look at the difference between Reactive Programming and Reactive Systems, both with concepts & code examples in Scala. 

Short bio: One day, a few years ago, Fabio Tiriticco was looking at existing technologies to realize his startup idea. An initial test with classic multi-threaded Java programming leads to successful-yet-ugly&painful results. That is when Scala & Akka came into sight. The startup didn't go very far, but the love for Reactive Systems stayed strong ever since. By day, Fabio works as a Tech Lead for Weeronline.nl, while at night he runs the Reactive Amsterdam meetup, which is about all things reactive -- with a soft spot for reactive architectures.
results.name: Reactive Programming or Reactive Systems?

results.description:
Program:

18:00 - Doors open & dinner

19:00 - We start the talk which will contain a hands-on part

21:00 - Official end

Abstract:

An introduction to the theory behind cybernetics and feedback control followed by the application of such methods in the controlling of code execution for mission-critical services and applications. Attendees get to practice the "act of control" on code executing within a Java virtual machine without actually writing any code but instead test driving various thought experiments in policing and prioritization of processing. 

No experience of Java coding required - only an understanding of threads and coding. For the hands-on part, you will need Java 8 to be pre-installed on your laptop though you can follow along with the speaker.

A fun, playful, and hopefully inspiring night for all those involved in designing, developing, and delivering systems managed autonomously.

Bio:

William Louth is renowned software product designer/developer and an experienced systems engineer with particular expertise in self-adaptive software runtimes, adaptive control, self-regulation (cybernetics), resilience engineering, software simulation & mirroring, application performance monitoring and management as well as cost execution optimization and scalability engineering.
results.name: Controlling Software Execution With Your Thoughts

results.description:
Program:

18:00 - Doors open & dinner

19:00 - We start the talk

21:00 - Official end

Session:
In this session I’ll give a high level overview of the Azure Cognitive Services API’s and will then focus the Computer Vision API in more depth. There will be code examples and live demos so let’s pray to the demo gods for a good network connection :). If there's some time left I'll also demonstrate the Azure Custom Vision service.
What do you learn: Better understanding of what Cognitive Services offers and how the Computer Vision API can be used in your applications.

Bio:

Marc Duiker is a Lead Consultant at Xpirit with a strong focus on Azure combined with extensive knowledge of web application development and content management systems (4x Sitecore MVP). He’s very much interested in serverless architectures and applications that involve Cognitive Services and Machine Learning. In his spare time Marc frequently visits old abandoned buildings to capture their beauty using his camera.
results.name: Improving your vision with Azure Cognitive Services
